 BOLIVIA HYDROCARBON SECTOR REFORM AND CAPITALIZATION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT SECTION A: DETAILED PROJECT DESCRIPTION I. SECTOR OVERVIEW Introduction 1. Bolivia's oil and gas sector has strong potential for attracting foreign direct investment and providing needed economic growth. However, for the last decade, it has not seen major progress partly because of the overwhelming predominance of the State through its national company, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Bolivianos (YPFB), and the limnited attractiveness of the Hydrocarbons Law. Salient Facts about the Sector 2. During the last decade, the following elements characterized the hydrocarbon sector in Bolivia: * steady decline in the production of liquids until the end of 1986 with an increase in 1994 and renewal of exports at the end of 1993. - stable production and export of natural gas to Argentina but steady decline in the price. * decline in the number of companies exploring in the country until 1988 and an increase of interest in Bolivia after 1990 new Hydrocarbons Law. * weakening of Govemment institutions dealing with the sector. * deterioration of YPFB's finances, and liquidity. * over-taxation of YPFB in the form of transfers of surplus to the Treasury. * considerable goverment interference in YPFB's day-to-day operations. * some degree of politicization and demoralization of YPFB's personnel. 3. High inflation and political instability in the country, particularly in the early part of the 1980s, have exacerbated the problems of the hydrocarbon sector. In addition, YPFB has experienced long and frequent delays in being paid by Argentina for its gas sales to YPF -- more than six months at times. This situation has led YPFB to delay its payments to its suppliers of natural gas and liquids, and to the service contractors. By the end of the decade, YPFB was the major company exploring in the
 - 2 - country. However, after the promulgation of the new Hydrocarbons Law in November 1990, new interest in Bolivia emerged again, particularly with Brazil natural gas market potential . 4. Exploration. As of April 1995, there were 15 operations contracts, three secondary recovery contracts and three association contracts. While this foreign participation in exploration is encouraging, it remains modest compared to the country natural gas potential, and the relative success obtained by the neighboring countries such as Argentina, Peru, and Colombia where the number of contracts signed is much more important and the areas under exploration cover a large part of the sedimentary basins of these countries. Furthermore, these contracts did not result in significant investments to stimulate the sector. In 1992, investments by oil companies reached US$150 million of which only US$76 million were in exploration. The number of oil companies including those operating under secondary recovery contracts reached twenty five by April 1995. These companies control about 24 blocks with an area of about 14 million hectares (about 23 percent of total potential acreage), while YPFB controls 26 blocks with an area of about 7.4 million hectares (about 12 percent of total). The signing of the natural gas sale purchase agreements between Bolivia and Brazil in August 1988 -- which was replaced by the one of October 1991 -- has created a renewed interest in Bolivia as a potential supplier of natural gas. This interest increased further after the signing of joint- venture agreements in July 1994 between YPFB and ENRON, and YPFB and BHP Petroleum for natural gas exports to Brazil and Chile, respectively. Interest in exploration will increase as a result of these last agreements and the likelihood of an export market for natural gas. 5. Reserves and Production. As of January 1995, were 56.9 there were 59 known oil and gas fields with remaining recoverable reserves in Bolivia. The geographical distribution of the fields where YPFB operates is as follows: 21 fields in the Area Boomerang-Chapare; 11 fields in the Central Area; and 16 fields in the southern part of the country. Private contractors, or "contratistas" operate the remaining 11 fields. These fields as well as the quasi totality of the exploratory efforts are in the area known as the "Area Tradicional", covering nearly one third of Bolivia. As of January 1995, the remaining proven oil and condensate reserves were 56.9 million barrel (MMBbl) and 71.3 MMBbl, respectively. The remaining proven gas reserves were 3.8 trillion cubic feet (TCF) while the probable gas reserves were 2.5 TCF. YPFB own production is about eighty percent of the total natural gas production and about seventy percent of total liquids' production. Total production peaked in 1973 at 47,000 barrels per day (BD) declining thereafter to less than 22,000 BD in 1986. Recent discoveries in the Chapare Area have helped increase the production to about 32,000 BD in 1995. The natural gas reserves base, while important, needs to be increased to support export of large volumes of natural gas to Brazil, Argentina and possibly Paraguay and Chile. 6. Drilling. As of February 1995, YPFB's Drilling Department, staffed with 917 employees or about 18.8 percent of total YPFB's staff, is the company's largest department. YPFB owns and operates nine drilling rigs and ten work over rigs. According to a recent evaluation of these rigs by Petro-Canada, only two rigs are new and nine are considered in good shape with nine being thirty two years and older. The equipment has a variety of manufacturers and is costly to maintain and operate. Field drilling personnel have solid experience and know-how, but, overall operational equipment/tools are either obsolete or inadequate, making drilling costly. In comparison with private drilling companies operating in Bolivia, YPFB's drilling cost is high.
 - 3 - 7. Refining. YPFB's refining available capacity is substantially higher than petroleum product demand; it amounts to 50,000 BD compared to a demand of 26,000 BD. The breakdown by refinery is: Sucre 3,000 BD (reprocessing only), Cochabamba 27,000 BD and Santa Cruz 20.000 BD. The production of refined petroleum products from three domestic refineries is approximately in balance with demand on a total product basis. Currently there are individual product imbalances, particularly small surpluses of gasoline, and shortages of diesel oil. These are due basically to the nature of the domestic crude produced, and to some extent, the limitations of refinery configuration. The plants are simple hydro-skimming refineries, designed to process the light, sweet crude and condensates which the country produces. Refineries produce about a quarter of the LPG consumed, and the balance comes from field gas plants. It does not appear that there will be a need to expand capacity or to build conversion capacity in the foreseeable future. 8. Distribution and Marketing. YPFB has a ownership of thirty bulk storage depots with loading racks, fifty three kerosene outlets, seven large LPG bottling plants and nineteen small one sixty three service stations (but operates only four), no road tankers, and one hundred and thirty three rail tank cars. The private sector owns and operate more than 171 service stations, and all river barges and tugs. YPFB performance in this area is quite satisfactory. Supply and distribution were never interrupted. However, marketing cost is high and investments for maintenance and modernization of installations were low, particularly during the last five years. 9. YPFB's Finances. YPFB's 1993 domestic sales amounted to about Bs2.067 billion while export, mostly natural gas to Argentina, amounted to about Bs604.9 million, the equivalent of US$451 million and US$132 million, respectively. Net profit amounted to about US$200 million. Total fixed assets were equal to about Bs3.655 billion, equivalent to about US$798 million of which production and gas plants represented fifty six percent, refining more than seven percent and pipeline twenty six percent. YPFB's long term debt stood at Bsl.412 billion equivalent to about US$308 million. Operating costs are considered high and liquidity of YPFB is poor. H. HYDROCARBON SECTOR ISSUES Sector Structure 10. Presently, the Government is the policy maker, the regulator and, as indicated above, the sole shareholder of YPFB. The National Secretariat of Energy (NSE) has supervisory authority for the hydrocarbon sector in the areas of policy making, regulation and coordination. The Directorate of Energy and Hydrocarbons (DGH), within NSE, exercises these functions by monitoring, regulating and enforcing the Hydrocarbons Law and related regulations. But DGH lacks the human and financial resources as well as the expertise and experience to do its job effectively. Moreover, the ability of NSE to influence YPFB and overall hydrocarbon policy is very limited. Under this structure NSE and DGH have had only very limited leverage in dealing with YPFB, and limited authority to perform their respective roles adequately.
 - 4 - Legal and Regulatory Framework 11. The Hydrocarbons Law of November 1990 is the legal document that established the policy and organization of the sector. This law was an improvement over the 1972 Hydrocarbon Law. It did open pipeline and downstream activities to the private sector participation, but has maintained YPFB's monopoly in upstream activities, i.e. exploration and production (E&P), allowing for the entry of the private sector through operations and/or association contracts. But since its enactment, the Government has not taken all the required steps to promote private investment in exploration or introduce a transparent bidding system. Moreover, the Government has neither changed the present role nor ownership of YPFB's, except for the following: introduction of an enhanced secondary recovery contract; the opening of marketing outlets under concession or supply agreement with YPFB; and the establishment of private natural gas distribution companies. 12. Operations and Association Contracts. The Hydrocarbon Law grants YPFB monopolistic control of exploration and production in the country. It also provides for two types of contract, under which investors may conduct exploration and production activities in Bolivia: * The Operations Contract. The basis of this contract is the 1971 Peruvian model (no longer in use) under which there is approximately a 50/50 sharing of measured gross production, with the contractor bearing all costs up to the "fiscalization - i.e supervision for compliance" or metering point but with all taxes deemed included in the State company's share. * The Association Contract. This contract is not based on any international precedent. It is essentially an operations contract with a superimposed equity participation option for YPFB, should it elect to participate in the development and production of a commercial discovery. Unlike the operations contract, it does not provide any new incentives. To date, only three association contracts have been signed, primarily for two reasons: (a) the relative un-attractiveness of the deal on a risk-weighted basis in comparison to what is available in other countries; and (b) private investor concerns that YPFB may have difficulty funding its share of development costs. 13. It is mainly the taxation regime of this law that hinders Bolivian competitiveness. Bolivia is mostly known as a gas prone country with potential of discovery in the proven traditional basins of only small oil and gas condensate fields. In addition, the law has several other weaknesses that discourage private foreign direct investment, among which: (i) the limited and inflexible contractual arrangements for upstream operations, i.e. exploration and production by obligating the foreign investor to be a partner of YPFB; (ii) no free disposition, export and import of crude oil, petroleum products and natural gas; and (iii) control by the government of crude oil, natural gas and petroleum products prices which create economic distortions and dis-incentives for investment. 14. Petroleum Regulations. With the assistance of UNDP, the previous Ministry of Energy and Hydrocarbons prepared more than 17 draft regulations implementing the new Hydrocarbons Law and dealing, among other things, with storage and distribution, oil blending service stations, compressed
 -5 - natural gas, transportation of liquids by pipeline. IDA was requested to comment on these drafts. Only six were issued. In general, they were rigid, very restrictive and continue to lend too much authority to and interference by YPFB. New regulations need to be drafted when the new Hydrocarbons Law is approved by the National Congress (NC). In addition to this work, IDA with funding from ESMAP, provided technical assistance for a study to analyze the economics of natural gas distribution in Bolivia, and the drafting of a gas code to: (i) promote substitution of LPG and diesel domestically; (ii) stimulate private sector participation in this activity, (iii) design the structure, authority, and responsibilities of the Government in this area; (iv) define broad principles for natural gas exports; (v) design tariff-setting principles, parameters, mechanisms for investors; and (vi) define rules for common access to gas pipeline transport and taxes on the end use of natural gas. The new administration that took office in August 1993 opted to have a single new Hydrocarbons Law which is under preparation and which would incorporate the main principles included in the draft gas code. Presently, this commodity is not explicitly taxed by the Government. Environmental Aspects 17. The Diagnostic Study of YPFB's operations and physical facilities have identified a number of environmental issues: (i) weak environmental capability within the company and lack of experience; (ii) weakness of institutions at NSE as well as at MOSDE with respect to environmental management, including monitoring and enforcement of environmental regulations; (iii) lack of environmental regulations, operational guidelines and procedures within the company; (iv) lack of regulatory capability and authority, and no viable means of enforcing regulations at the level of NSE as well as at the level of MOSDE; (v) insufficient awareness and acceptance of the environmental impact on operations within YPFB, NSE and MOSDE; (vi) environmental impact on areas accessed for seismic and exploration drilling; (vii) gas flaring and related environmental impact such as noise; and (viii) environmental impact resulting from new and more intense exploration and production activity. Other environmental issues include: * impact of petroleum activities particularly exploration and production in remote rural areas on indigenous people, wildlife, ecology and declared protected areas. * above-ground pipelines and possible oil spills. * lack of procedures, material, and equipment for emergency countermeasure. 18. The study concluded that YPFB has had a poor environmental record in terms of protecting the soil and subsoil, rivers, forests and air from effluent during all aspects of petroleum activities. The proposed project will address identified problems in these areas. Two in-depth environmental audits of all YPFB physical installations and operations are being carried out by two separate firms and a mitigation plan will be developed to remedy most of the damages identified. These audits will extend to areas covered by existing or potential private exploration and/or development projects and will also address social as well as ecological issues of remote indigenous people. They will be reviewed by a legal consultant to determine their implications and Government's responsibility. The Government has already indicated that it intends to assume responsibility for all such environmental concern. The Government also intends to implement the recommendations of these environmental audits. 19. The Government recognizes that, if it does not adequately address the environmental problems that petroleum operations cause and the related measures required to protect indigenous people, serious consequences would occur and would have negative repercussions which would hinder further private oil exploration. In addition, the Government is also aware of the need to address current flows and installations design issues and their environmental and social impacts. The project will address these issues through the promulgation of a defined set of petroleum regulations, norms, operational guidelines, and provision of training of personnel in NSE as well as in MOSDE. Furthermore, the establishment of working group in NSE dedicated to environmental aspects and supported by
 -7 - environmental experts which will lead to the establishment of an Environmental Unit in NSE will address these issues. Funds from the credit will be provided to carry out these tasks in coordination with those which are planned for addressing environmental issues in the power sector. These tasks will be carried out in close coordination and under the guidance and leadership of the MOSDE and in cooperation with the oil companies. More details are provided in Attachment 1. Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Bolivianos (YPFB) 20. Role of YPFB. YPFB as a state company plays a dominant role in the petroleum industry in Bolivia. By far, it is the oldest company in the country. Private companies have used YPFB as a reliable partner, a source of information and also as a source of help to carry out many of their operations. With a fairly good discovery success ratio, it was able to provide the energy requirements the country needs for its economic development. Although YPFB is in a privileged exploration position it controls only 7.4 million hectares out of a total of about 69 million hectares of sedimentary basins. However, because of Government budgetary constraints, YPFB cannot get the financial resources to actively explore this acreage. The privileged position which YPFB hold stems from the Hydrocarbons Law which grants it the monopoly in exploration and production, and a special role to act on behalf of the state. In addition, YPFB is in a unique position of funding a significant portion of the Government's budget. But this fiscal relationship to the state budget has also restricted its ability to have the financial resources in order to plan and manage its investment programs and its operations in general. 21. Government Interference in YPFB Operations. Because of YPFB's predominant role in the economy and the impact it has on local and regional business, many segments of the Government have been interfering in its operations -- central, provincial and local Govemments as well as incumbent political parties This interference covers: (i) appointment and dismissal of personnel; (ii) procurement process; and (iii) insistence on continued operation of uneconomic units, such as the Sucre refinery. This has caused productivity and efficiency to be low thus breeding instability among personnel and the hiring of unnecessary personnel. However, since January 1994, YPFB's personnel has decline and as of April 1995, its total work force decreased by about 12 percent. III. GOVERNMENT POLICY ACTIONS Government's Capitalization Policy Actions 22. Significant policy measures have been taken in order to lay the foundation for the reform of the sector and the capitalization of YPFB. These measures are characterized by the passage of three important laws that open the way for the Government to implement its reform program. The first is the Capitalization Law (Law No. 1544) which was approved by the NC on March 21, 1994. This law, in particular, authorizes the Executive Office to: (i) transfer all assets of the public enterprises, including YPFB, for the creation of " Sociedades de Economia Mixta" (MECs) or joint venture companies; (ii) capitalize each public enterprises including YPFB through a Supreme Decree; (iii) transfer the State shares in these MECs to the Bolivian citizens, age 21 and above; (iv) establish a
 - 8 - "Fideicomiso" or Trust Fund which will be the depositoiy of these shares until the creation of Pension Funds; and ()i) to let the Treasury assume, prior to sale, part or the whole financial liabilities of these companies. 23. The second law is the SIRESE Law (Law No. 1600) which was enacted recently on October 28, 1994 by the NC. This law defines the activities that will be regulated and the authority responsible for regulations cnforcement as well as the mechanisms in case of litigation and complaints by either the investor, the consumer or the public authority. It establishes a General Superintendency and five Sectorial Superintendencies, among them that of the hydrocarbon sector. The law defines clearly the functions and responsibilities of each of these units, their funding and the way the respective Superintendent is designated. 24. Finally, the third law is the General Tax Law (Law 1606) amending that of May 20, 1985 (Law 843), and which was enacted on December 22, 1994, by the NC. This Law establishes, in particular, a new common corporate tax regime of 25 percent on taxable income for companies involved in exploration, exploitation, refining, processing, pipeline transport and marketing. In addition, the law introduces an excise tax on petroleum products which should not be in excess of Bs 1.50 per liter or equivalent unit without specifying which products will be subjected to this tax. Regulations implementing these laws will be promulgated in the near future. The passage of these fundamental laws to achieve this program and the agreement on the Policy Framework Paper with the IMF are clear signals of the Govemment commitment. They also establish a clearer framework for implementing this T A and reflect a direction of reform whichi IDA agrees with. Government's Hydrocarbons Sector Policy Actions 25. These policy actions specific to the sector which were pledged by the Govemment and which will be supported by this project include: * redefinition of the relative roles of the government --including central, province and local (lovemments -- and the private sector in the hydrocarbons sector. * reorganization of the sector by the passage of a new Hydrocarbon Law, including an internationally competitive fiscal regime and the promulgation of new regulations implementing the law to attract private investment as the State withdraws from this sector. a r eform of the pricing and taxation system of petroleum products, LPG and natural gas, that establishes explicit excise taxes on petroleum products. The new tax regime will help restore price transparency at each stage of the industry, and thus, stimulate greater competition in downstream operations. * capitalization of YPFB so that the resulting company or companies will compete fully in all stages of the sector and have a contractual relationship with the Government for exploration and production as well as pipelines, similar to any other private company. The Government will open a portion of the exploration acreage presently held by YPFB to
 - 9 - exploration by private companies, preferably through simple and attractive contractual arrangements in the form of concession. * issuance of environmental regulations, standards and norms that would be legally enforceable as well as strengthening of Government capacity to monitor environmental aspects of hydrocarbons activities and mitigate damages that may be identified by environmental audits of YPFB. 26. Draft of the Hydrocarbons Law is in final stage (see para. 31 below for more detail) before submission to the cabinet and the NC. There are still some pending issues that need to be resolved. These concern in particular the upstream (E&P) fiscal regime, the organization of the sector, and the future of existing Operations Contracts. The fiscal regime will be reexamined in the light of the new General Tax Law discussed in para. 24 above. In particular, national royalty should be readjusted upward to compensate for the low corporate tax rate approved by this law. However, the enactment of the Hydrocarbons Law remains the most important building block to be put in place in order to bring to fruition: (i) an adequate reorganization and governance of the sector that would capture the economic rent and bring sufficient revenue to the government as well as long tenn sustainability and stability of the sector; (ii) an environment which is competitive enough to attract major private sector investment; and (iii) an acceptable trade off among all these considerations and those specifically related to YPFB capitalization which are somewhat dependent on the way the sector will be reorganized. doc.abstracts: The objective of the Hydrocarbon Sector Reform and capitalization Technical Assistance Project is to assist the Government in the analysis, planning design and execution of its reform program for the hydrocarbon sector, inclusive of institutional strengthening and the capitalization of Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Bolivianos (YPFB). The project comprises three components. The first component, legal and reg Fr%frulatory Framework, including analytical studies and preliminary activities for the design of the overall legal and regulatory framework for the reform of, and future development in the sector. The second component, capitalization of YPFB, including pre-capitalization analytical studies and preliminary activities and preparation for the capitalization transaction of Mixed Economy Coporations (MECs). Institutional strengthening is the third component, and will enable the National Secretariat of Energy (NSE) to carry out the reforms and monitor the sector by: 1) strengthening of DGH to be involved in prepatory activities leading to the establishment, in its reforms, policy making in the area of safety and operation standards, monitoring contracts, and development of an Project Unit which will carry out these functions.
